SEN support and the graduated approach  
In County Durham we expect every child who requires SEN support to have an 
individual SEN Support plan. This must work towards a clear set of expected outcomes and detail the ‘additional to’ or ‘different from’ provision they are receiving. From year 9 onwards, there should be a greater focus on ‘preparing for adulthood’ 
within the plan.
 
At this stage - with your agreement - a pupil would normally be recorded on the SEN 
register.   
There is a County Durham template of the SEN support plan available to all schools, 
but they can use their own, as long as it outlines:  
• Your child’s strengths  
• Your child’s needs/difficulties  
• The desired outcomes (matched to the needs)  
• The provision that is being made

When your son with learning disabilities turns 18 in Durham, his financial support will transition to adult services, which may involve a financial assessment to determine his contribution towards care services.

**Key Information:**
- **Financial Assessment:** According to the Care Act 2014, local authorities can conduct a financial assessment to determine how much an adult can contribute towards their social care costs. This means your son may be asked to contribute to the cost of his care based on his financial situation (Document 1, Page 3).
- **Charging Policy:** Charges for adult social care services will commence from the start of the service, and the policy is designed to comply with the Care Act 2014, ensuring fairness and compliance with equality legislation (Document 1, Page 3).

**Practical Next Steps:**
- **Contact Information:** For more detailed information about the financial assessment process and potential charges, you can visit the Durham County Council website at [durham.gov.uk](https://www.durham.gov.uk/article/5765/How-much-you-will-have-to-pay-for-care-and-support-services).
- **Further Assistance:** If you have specific questions or need assistance with the transition process, consider reaching out to the adult social care team in Durham for guidance.

The available documents don't provide specific information about the exact changes in financial support amounts or specific services your son will receive. For personalized advice, contacting Durham County Council directly would be beneficial.
